job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Aurora, CO
pros: Exceptional quality of nurses are created here. Overall you can tell a big difference between nurses who started out here, vs ones who newly transferred. The dedication and quality is palpable, and across all disciplines. You become very proud to say to patients that you’re glad they made it to your hospital. There are many opportunities for education and programs for career advancement. You are highly recognized for your hard work. Benefits are impressive, some of the best.
cons: You don’t get paid what you’re worth. Although it’s great experience and the effort is admirable, the salary increase for hard work done for the hospital to advance it as well as advancing your career is barely minimal. Does not follow inflation or match the national average. Pays an exorbitant amount of travelers because staff retention is so poor due to mismatch in pay for effort. Effort to just meet expectations for annual appraisals requires a lot of unpaid work at home.

review_title: Avoid this job at all costs
job_title: Virtual Health Tech III in Aurora, CO
pros: The cons immediately outweigh any positive thing so significantly that it would be unethical to even mention.
cons: You will develop mental health issues. Hospital policies will force you to create enemies with the nursing staff. You will not be respected by nurses, management, doctors. You will cry at least once or more working in this role in the first few months because of sheer stress. You will not be able to enjoy your days off because you will be so tired, no matter how smart you are. During the summer you will sweat at your desk for 12 hours. You will never consistently be able to take any more than a 15 minute break during your 12 hour shift. You will work with other employees that are so burnt out that everyone around you is on some kind of anxiety medicine or just raw dog struggling. You will learn that the nursing staff does not know what they are doing when it comes to cardiac rhythms. Hospital policy is all that matters to them. Not the patients. You will encounter employees who threaten, stalk, and verbally abuse other employees and they will not be fired, nor will they suffer any appropriate consequence for their disregard for patients, people, or their fellow coworkers. Absolutely, hands down the worst place to work in Colorado. Do not work here. The patient load is dangerously high and it is a disservice to any patient requiring telemetry, pulse ox, or capnography monitoring.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Aurora, CO

They talk about how great the pension package is all the time (in order to justify low wages)

cons: The culture is absolutely toxic, HR and leadership do not respond to suggestions or concerns, unsafe staffing levels, low pay compared to surrounding hospitals, no hazard pay for working in unsafe conditions, work life balance is neither encouraged nor possible, senior management only cares about promoting themselves and getting raises, and not providing the same for the staff.

job_title: Physician Recruiter in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: UCHealth provides great healthcare and has very good benefits for employees.
cons:
Physician Recruitment at UCHealth has the worst, most toxic management team that I have EVER experienced in all of my years of working. They might as well install a revolving door because of the extremely high turnover rate.

The manager was a joke, didn't support the employees and was absent most of the time.

The director likes to belittle and publicly embarrass new employees - a real dragon. 

When I asked the manager about this, she said the director likes to put new employees through 'boot camp' their first 3 or 4 months. Honestly, she is just a very unhappy person and she never let up, not even after 3 or 4 months. NOTHING was ever good enough for her.

Typically, new employees last about 6 months and just decide that they cannot take the abuse. 

Even after several people reached out to HR, completely out of desperation, nothing happened. Upper management and HR just didn't care enough to help out a slew of really good, hard-working employees.

Honestly, working there has only hurt my career because I left after 6 months. Hard to explain to perspective employers how toxic and stressful it was to work for this dynamic-duo.

job_title: Certified Sterile Processing Technician in Aurora, CO
pros: 1. Cutting edge of medicine- I learned a lot from the OR staff.
cons:
1. Discussing pay or comparing wages was punished, retaliation was the norm. 

2. If you weren't able to charm management and forcibly grab their attention then you would never receive positive feedback. 

3. Management would also believe and reward negative gossip from those spreading rumors.

4. It was not a merit based reward system. Those doing well were constantly gossiping,(often cruelly) and never received criticism. There was no recognition of hardworking staff, in fact; the hardest workers were the least appreciated and frequently insulted.

 For example; management bullied one guy into taking almost every single shift needing coverage. He thought he was the only person available because they'd always ask him to take shifts with no warning in advance. In reality they never even asked anyone else to cover, and mocked him for being available/ having no life. No gratitude whatsoever.

5. No career path. They actually eliminated the position I was originally hired for and I was stuck getting paid about $4 less than my coworkers (and less than new-hires) because my temporary position became permanent.

6. Management decides when to fire people, regardless of the actual validity of a termination. They watch the department cameras to catch their target making mistakes, and reports it to HR. In most cases the victim quits to avoid being fired.

review_title: Physicians are treated poorly in this organization !
job_title: Physician in Denver, CO
pros: There is some schedule flexibility.
cons:
UCHealth used to be a good place to work, but not anymore. It is the typical corporatization of healthcare, horrible bureaucracy, poor physician leadership etc
Physicians have no autonomy at all. You are constantly told to work more and see more patients. It is all about RVUs and percentiles. There is no interest in quality of care. There is no interest in keeping their best doctors happy. It is all about UCHealth's expansion. They are obsessed in becoming the most dominant healthcare organization in Colorado and that at all costs. Physicians are obligated to see a lot of new patients, when they have no availability to see their established patients. It takes months for a patient to get in to see a specialist. When you try to refer patients outside UCHealth, so that they can get better care, the leadership pulls you in meetings and you get scolded.
And did I mention that the physicians benefits are below average ?
The sad part is that all the other big healthcare corporations in CO are the same or worst. Small private practices cannot survive financially and they are swallowed by these big corporations. Signing with them gives you the illusion of job stability, but they treat you like they own you. "Take it or leave it!"
Sometimes it really feels like even the receptionists or the MAs are treated with more respect than their physicians.
Are you a physician who envisions having some level of autonomy in the way you practice? Well, then this is not the job for you. Here you do what you are told. It is all about "the production".
More recently, they started hiring lots of NPs and PAs, because they simply do not get enough MDs interested in their job positions. So my advice is to stay away from UCHealth and find yourself a job somewhere else.

review_title: A great experience with life changing memories.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Nursing staff are fantastic, hard working professionals. Great opportunity for the new grad to receive the experience needed to be successful in their career with wonderful support from nursing education. Excellent health care benefits and self-scheduling in nursing areas which really allows you to be in control of your work week. Great team of physician leaders who are supportive of nursing staff.
cons: Focus has drifted from supporting the bedside nurse with various initiatives to expecting nurses to manage care for 7-8 patients. This translates into the nurse having up to 11-12 different patients in a 12 hour shift when patients are discharged and new admissions come in. Managers are told to wear their scrubs and work a 12 hour shift in addition to their regular 10 hours already worked since nursing staff are in short supply. Nursing has been forced to accept this high patient to nurse ratio as normal when in truth funding can be obtained to create a healthier work environment. HRD does not solicit nor entice expert nurses to Memorial since they know the better place to be is in Denver. Focus is on graduate nurses and not experienced nurses.

review_title: Very poor executive and unit leadership - all talk, no action
job_title: Registered Nurse in Aurora, CO
pros: I had wonderful coworkers. We made a great team, always helped each other. That was the only thing that kept me going at this facility.
cons: Executive leadership always talks about how they’re “working on hiring more staff”, I heard this constantly for over two years straight as the nurses and CNAs were flexed up every shift. My license was always at stake with unsafe ratios and patients that should have been in an ICU, but weren’t because there were no beds available. I had honestly the worst nurse manager I’ve ever had in my life, HIGH on favoritism, always worried about your personal life, asks employees to be her “unit snitches”. It was so disgusting and this lady has worked at UCHealth for about thirty years. Coworkers always reported her to HR and she was investigated several times, but nothing was ever done because UCHealth obviously does not give a damn about their employees, just the bottom dollar. If a patient assaults the NURSE very badly, management will ask you what YOU did wrong to make it happen and they will kiss the patient’s backside. UCHealth is also one of the worst paying systems for nurses in the Denver area so definitely look elsewhere if you want to be paid what you’re worth. “Raises” there are completely insulting. Also you have to pay for parking which although minor, is annoying.

job_title: Permanent Charge Nurse in Aurora, CO
pros: It's a good place to get experience as a new grad, and thanks to the high turnover and burnout rate, you'll have plenty of opportunity to advance.
cons: The "non profit" label on this hospital is a joke. They have outstanding operating margins, and their executives are all one percenters. Yet they still tell concerned staff that taking care of the poor in Denver and Aurora is not an essential part of their mission. And lest you think the revenue is being invested in staff so they can take better care of patients, think again. Night and weekend staff took a substantial pay cut this year, but are being worked harder than ever. Floors run short regularly, with a lot of empty promises from upper leadership about hiring. Despite the inability to keep staff nurses around, the hospital continues to expand and the system keeps acquiring new properties. UC Health is sinking millions of dollars into expansion and executive salaries, yet reduces RN pay and refuses to adjust staffing to match acuity. Leaders have absolutely no concern for or clue about how overworked front line staff are. Ultimately, it's the patients who suffer, and the mix of high acuity, inexperienced nurses, and routine short staffing will show its deleterious effects on patient care.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Fort Collins, CO
pros: None that I can think of. Job security for those willing to stay in their position.
cons: Low pay. Only HR can disclose pay ranges and that is not disclosed by management. This makes job hunting nearly impossible since the pay is guarded like a trade secret. Doctors call all the shots, regardless of HR And or management. HR is only there to back up the revenue producers, which are the doctors. Doctors get paid by the codes they use, and revenue is incentivized by the use of codes. Bonuses are paid by the use of codes, making treatment a numbers game, taking away from the authenticity of patient care. UCHealth has become a corporate machine, based solely off of metrics. If you want to truly contribute to the care process this is not the place for you. As an employee, I often wonder how the hypocritical oath can even be applied to a pure money machine such as this. Glass ceiling institution.

review_title: A great place to work but loosing its allure.
job_title: Unit Assistant II in Fort Collins, CO
pros: It has a great reputation as a quality healthcare system. The nursing staff genuinely cares and are for the most part excited to be their doing what they do. When I started here they strived to get the highest quality staff and therefore provide high quality benefits and culture. They are deservedly a magnet status hospital. It the time I left they were above average wages for the area.
cons: It feels as though they are loosing much of what is making it such a great place. More and more staff are part time making lateral movement harder. Wages and benefits are decreasing. The care that was being taken to make it a world-class health care system isn't being taken as much and the culture is starting to lack because if it. With the coming of "Obama-care" they are fearing the worst and it is conveyed in how they are approaching the issue with staff.

job_title: Supervisor in Univ of Northern Colorado, CO
pros: Caring individuals at the bedside...providing direct care...still have a chance if they start  engaging and listening to those who have been in health care more than 10 years.
cons: Leadership significantly negatively altered culture due to their classic error in trying to reduce the budget by slashing labor cost blindly. History constantly repeats itself because young hot shot executive leadership think they know better than those who have weathered the ups and downs of multiple economic turns. They bring in young inexperienced staff and leaders who are arrogant and lack real life experience to make decisons....reinventing the same broken wheels of Healthcare instead of listening to and respecting the wisdom and knowledge of those who went before them. The evidence that would  lead to success is there...egos of the current leadership is blocking the opportunity to break out of the cycle of failure.

job_title: Staff RN in Aurora, CO
pros: Wonderful nurses and staff team work.
cons: I have worked for University of Colorado Hospital for more than 20 years as a Medical-Surgical Nurse.  Everything changed when UCH became invisible under the umbrella of UCHealth. They pushed out the best management this hospital ever had. Bruce Schroffel actually cared about the staff. The new administration supposedly did this at University of Pittsburgh too. Now the focus is on growth and finances. There are not enough nurses and not enough staff to help the nurses. It seems like it is now all new grads and nobody like me with experience. If you are admitted here as a patient, you are likely to fall because the staff can't get to you quickly enough. It used to be that nurse stayed here for a long time until they retired.  Now we have a rotating door and mostly new grads.I get called to come in every day that I am off. because of too many patients.  I have no privacy away from work.  I'm leaving and going to Denver Health where they have reasonable nurse patient ratios and a supportive management. I'm also making more money there and I can continue to contribute to my 401K. They may not be a Magnet hospital, but I no longer believe in Magnet hospitals after the last few years.......

job_title: Registered Nurse in Aurora, CO

review_title: It's all about the money now.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Loveland, CO
pros: UC Health isn't afraid to spend money on patient services like high tech equipment and fancy buildings and high end décor.  If you want the latest and greatest technologies this is the place.
cons: Completely left customer service as a thing of the past.  Great customer service in health care allows a person TIME to process and heal.  But it's all about money now.  Under previous CEO Rulon Stacey the PVH system was a coveted place to work with very high employee satisfaction and a stellar reputation that health care providers were top notch experienced care givers.  Now it's scared mangagers, new grads (because they are cheap and hungry and in debt), and employees that can't leave.  After the UC take over PVH lost it's soul.  Such a shame.  Patients get the shaft in the end.

review_title: Be careful of the department you apply to for a job.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Denver, CO
pros: None worth mentioning as the pay is less than most places and benefits are not worth taking the job.
cons: HR has lazy employees who are supposed to assist employees in need but they don't reply to emails, phone calls or if you go to them in person.  The company states that patients come first so they don't care about employees, but without employees the higher ups and those on the board will have to do all the jobs themselves.  They might want to check into some managers who have a BIG turnover in their departments. The job you apply for won't necessarily be the one you will do and make sure to get everything in writing. You may get paid $15 hr but someone who is less qualified will get $18 for the same job. Career opportunities are great because they have such a big turnover so if you need a job apply and expect to wait at least 3 to 5 months for an interview. Good luck you will need it.

review_title: Don't let the non-profit status fool you: It's all about the money here.
job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Aurora, CO
pros: Excellent benefit package, including pension plan; very talented clinical staff and knowledgeable operations staff. World-class performance in particular specialties.
cons: Aggressive project time frames, particularly in the Epic project. Poor work-life balance, long hours, unpaid overtime (for salaried workers), and heavy emphasis on and political power in the revenue cycle organization. They take care of patients' health and in collecting the bill as fast as possible--paying attention to employees' well-being is, sadly, not really a priority. Lack of understanding in UCH of the community provider needs emergent from the merger with Poudre Valley and Memorial Health Systems. Insular mindset on the part of University of Colorado Hospital leadership as pertains to the merger. Insufficient representation of Poudre Valley and Memorial Management in the new University of Colorado Health organization (a product of the merger of UCH and the others above). Mass uncertainty about the future among the rank-in-file. High turnover in the IT organization as a result of all of the above.

job_title: Director in Aurora, CO
pros: Benefits match the industry, fairly strong financial position.  I still think the system has great potential, but will be unrealized unless changes are made.
cons: Prior to the partnership the culture was built on a true desire to provide excellent care - both from a quality and patient satisfaction perspective.  This was done through making sure to hire and retain great people (and moving others on who didn't fit the vision).  One of our partners did this better than we did, but we did not learn from them (PVHS).  That has significantly changed and we have become just another health system.  Probably still OK to get care, but not a place to advance careers in a way that capitalizes on the potential of our industry.  Recent leadership hires have not gone well, and are seen as a joke within the system.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Pension plan rewards longevity, Health Insurance can fit multiple needs, Yearly Raises and Bonuses are common.  Generally nice place to work and educated quality employees.
cons: Profit Driven (for a non-profit, funny huh?),  No Maternity Leave -Terrible and Disappointing (even from a male's standpoint) that there is not maternity leave and your coworkers who have kids are forever screwed out of vacation time - despicable in 2016 - I don't have kids but feel sorry for those who do with this company's policies.

review_title: Beware if you try to do the right thing.
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Denver, CO
pros: They used to have free snacks and coffee all-day
cons: There were plenty of times that coworkers were violating HIPPA regulations and when bringing it to the office's attention I was given write-ups. When having a sit down with the higher-ups, they allowed no room for discussion of how poorly the supervisor dealt with the issues. From that point on I was targeted constantly. Also, they make a habit of paying POC less than others. Even when the POC has more experience in the medical field. Honestly, the pay is not worth your time in dealing with a conglomerated with no heart and little to no diversity in the higher levels, meaning if your supervisor says you're wrong, you're wrong.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Fort Collins, CO
pros: None, anymore. I used to be proud to work here. Now I'm embarrassed. I plan to leave by the end of this year.
cons: No leadership or accountability among so-called leaders and management. They like people to smile and be yes men even though they are stabbing us in the back with new "changes" daily. Policies keep changing, people are flying out the doors, the local paper won't cover citizen concerns because the hospital spends so much money advertising in it, but there really should be an investigation into how they run things. Very top-heavy organization, a lot of CEOs, COOs, CFOs, etc but they keep cutting staff. They have not been forthcoming about changes. Staff satisfaction took a major dive and then they accuse employees of having a bad attitude- duh, what did you expect? They are afraid of new ideas or new blood.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Denver, CO
pros:
Great health benefits
Large company with multiple sites

They will drive employees to death making them do SO much more than which is required of them.  I was Manager for a department with no Director above me.  I was Manager, Clinical and Director of department.   I applied for a director position but was told I don't qualify. Excuse me?  I have all the qualifications of the Director JD taken right off HR site.  They have 2 of them, 1 generic and 1 department specific. No advancing here, they expect you to do your job, the job of your staff and jobs your "not qualified" for with little to no acknowledgement, no thank you-good job.  Snobby administration.

review_title: The best company I have ever worked for.
job_title: Medical Assistant in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
Memorial Hospital has some awesome benefits, including competitive pay (which increases as needed with standard of living increase), great 403a accounts with Memorial matching up to 3% of contributions, great health insurance (free high deductible plan for the employee and their entire family), an employee gym, a discounted daycare that is run by Memorial, great paid time off, and the chance for many bonuses.

I believe that management creates a positive/encouraging environment and there is plenty of communication coming from upper management.

In my specific office, I am blessed with great co-workers, providers, and managers.
cons: There has been lots of change, and sometimes people have felt insecure about it. So far, I feel like all the changes have been for the better and I do not know of anyone who has been negatively affected by them. But there still are times when it feels like we're on shaky ground.

job_title: RN II in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Still some genuine caring staff that haven't given up and work together as a team. I like my direct supervisor.
cons: People are leaving in droves because of the day to day stress of continual change and increases in nurse to patient ratios. The lack of caring exhibited when 5 hospitals merged into one huge company is astounding. They are dismantling their best hospitals piece meal. Pay is uneven across the company for equal jobs.  After 10 years I'm finally considering leaving myself.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Aurora, CO
pros: There is little to be happy at working at UC health.  They expect you to be on call 24 hours a day and be able to work every shift no matter your senority.  There are even times where they ask you to work off the clock if they are short on staff.  Helping people get better is the only benefit to working there
cons: There are so many it will be hard to fit it all here.  The pay is very low compared to other hospitals.  Managment is trying so hard to save money that it affects the nurses and doctors job of giving good healthcare.  The benefits are just ok nothing to be super happy about.  Most of my coworkers are awesome but everyone hates their job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Aurora, CO

Some groups are allowed to form clicks and act out  treating others without respect.  They try to run the departments they work in some are even allowed to be labeled "role models" on annual reviews which is a joke management is in control /to blame for this as well.

job_title: in Colorado Springs, CO

review_title: Good place to start as a new grad RN, just get out after your first 2 yrs are up
job_title: Registered Nurse in Aurora, CO
pros: Excellent new grad RN program, supportive about continuing education, very large facility ( this can be a con too), you get a free turkey every Thanksgiving, although who knows how long this will last ;)
cons:
I work on the surgical floor. These are my frustrations: Expensive, not- so-competitive benefits (my health insurance rates tripled when I went to part time- $266 per pay period) management does not listen, Med-surg charge nurses take up to 4 patients at night, day charges can take 1 patient during the day. I've been fighting this a long time, this is dangerous and defeats the purpose of a charge nurse. You also have to be on a committee so once a month on your day off you will be expected to attend a committee meeting and report back to your unit about it. 
You will be pressured to get certification in whatever your specialty is, but there is no pay increase associated with it. 
The only way to really increase your pay is to "level up" which is a lot of work, and only applies to university hospital. If you leave to go to another hospital, you lose your level 3 or 4 title. 
Not worth it in my opinion. To be totally transparent: I've been an RN for 3 years and I make $26.30 base pay. I started there as a new grad. 
University loves to brag about how they are the best hospital, but the way they run their hospital does not reflect this. New grad RNs can expect to rotate night and day shifts for the first couple of years. They got rid of their weekend incentive agreement a couple years ago, which offered a bonus for RNs that signed contracts to work weekends. They just nixed the night contract too. This is a huge pay cut for RNs who work exclusively nights. For full time RNs, this is a $4000 pay cut per year. Management says they "might" increase the base pay, but I doubt it. 
Recently, some senior nurses who had been there 6 plus years who hadn't rotated in years were told it they were not a level 3 or higher, they were required to work one night shift/month. We've had a lot of turnover recently as you can imagine. 
Overall, I feel like I'm continuously expected to do more with less (I know this is universal in healthcare) however, I have friends who work at other hospitals in the Denver metro area, and when I tell them about my situation at work, they are shocked, and tell me their hospital does not operate like that. 
University has high expectations of their RNs, but don't offer incentives and pay that match this. They treat their RNs like they are disposable and in some instances I've seen them push senior nurses out the door. Not a great work environment. Budget always trumps patient safety.

review_title: No longer a good place to work
job_title: Analyst in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: None that I can think of now. Everything has went downhill in the last 5 years. Used to be a great employer, now it's not. So no Pros at all.
cons:
Management turnover has been insane, and will continue to be insane, because University of Colorado--UCHealth--is poorly managed (They bought/leased Memorial). Memorial has been poorly managed for the last 5 or 6 years, but there was a lot of hope when UCHealth came in and bought us. 

Unfortunately, that hope was misplaced. As an organization, we have been losing money for the last 7 years. UCHealth came in and put in emergency cost-cutting procedures. But then they lost their CEO, and now they are fumbling for what to do. Everything is disorganized and LOSING money. Just look up Memorial articles the local papers (Gazette and the Independent) and you will see all of the financial issues.

The reason for these issues is because of poor management and also because of very low morale. I have been a full-time employee here for over 10 years, and I would NOT bring my family here for care. Trust me on this, care here has gotten very poor. Nurse morale is way down.

Most of the causes for these issues can be narrowed down to mismanagement, executives who don't know what they are doing, and way way way too much middle management. Lots of middle managers need to be shown the door. 

Also, the entire Memorial organization is very oudated when it comes to computers. Most of the staff does NOT know how to work a computer, and our IT (formerly called IS) department doesn't know either. Many of the computer programs still run very outdated Windows versions and many even still use DOS for their programs. Basically they have not updated their technical infrastructure since 1987. I'm not kidding or exaggerating. I do think that this may change with UCHealth coming in, but seriously?! 

HR is a joke and have no idea how modern companies are supposed to be run. 

Our CEO and CFO recently got fired, on the SAME day with no notice! That pretty much sums up how bad things are. The new CEO, George Hayes, won't be here for long either. His wife didn't even move here, so most employees think that he'll be on the job for only a year or two at the most. (it's 2014 as I write this.) 

By the way, in the last 6 years, we have been through four CEOS. yeah, 4 in six years. That's how crazy it is. And the current one won't be here long either--he doesn't even live here in town.

review_title: Be very leery of this hospital before you apply here!
job_title: Staff RN in Aurora, CO
pros: There are many opportunities to see multiple medical situations and for a new graduate as a nurse or therapist this should be a great opportunity for you to experience things you might not and other facilities In town.
cons: University of Colorado Hospital Has an outward appearance of healthcare excellence, however after being an employee for a while you start to see extremely concerning scenarios throughout the hospital. Oftentimes clinicians are  overloaded with patients to an unsafe standard. Nurses can have up to four patients in the ICU without any relief staff willing to come in.  Respiratory therapy often has complained about having triple the workload of any hospital in the state of Colorado. As a clinician in the ICU at university I have seen mini unsafe situations involving residents /new doctors  not make good medical decisions. Management and administration have a culture of abuse and cover-up questionable instance that happen at the hospital. Just In the last 12 months there have been three staff members who had committed suicide on campus. None of these incidences made the media because the media has been paid off by the hospital.  A neurosurgeon committed suicide in his car in the parking lot of the hospital and nobody spoke about it! Another employee hung himself from the balcony of the hospital and staff members that saw the incident were asked to go home and or resign from their job.  The Hospital is so voracious in their ability to squash any negative reviews  that this review will be taken down as soon as they find it. Lastly HR is not your friend it is there to protect the hospital and not the employee. If you feel that you have a situation that is serious enough to go to HR just simply find a new job!

review_title: Don't work here!  What a nightmare!
job_title: Radiology Department in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Friendly employees.   Pay was pretty good.  Merging with the University should be a really good thing in the future.
cons:
Ex Military Management talk at you as if you are in the military.  Literally getting in your face and talking to you like Sargent Carter on the Gomer Pile Show.  It seemed like it was  just for fun, or so it seemed and then writing you up about it and in some cases, getting people fired.   Do they get a bonus for this?   
I did not sign up for the military.   
Threats of insubordination that don't even fit the definition. 
 People just disappear and are never seen again, even though it is said that there is a protocol and there are meetings and warning, write ups, etc...  
TERMINATED.  No warnings or write ups.   I moved across the country to be terminated  for reasons (one of them completely made up and no matter how I tried, they would not look at the proof against it, or take it off my record),  that would normally get a write up or warning.  They put a negative mark on my career that will make getting a job nearly impossible.  I thought that the University would not have handled my situation this way, but when I asked for help, they did not step in.    
When I called for my COBRA papers, they said my "Whole Group" had a computer glitch and would be late.  'Whole group'?  How many people are "LET GO" for a 'whole group' of cobra papers to go out, what, weekly? I was approved for Unemployment, so I obviously didn't do anything serious or illegal.  WHAT THE?  
They use the "At Will" State Law as an excuse to be horrible to people that just want to go to work and do their jobs.  We had this law where I am from, but never saw this interpretation of the law.
Employees are aware of this law and are in constant fear of being fired. Very, very sad.

BULLIES!  What a nightmare of an experience!
